text: thanks Shana! here I am. It’s been intense, I worked all evenings very late but I sent it and let’s see what the company thinks.I would say that whenever I’m working on a intense TV serie, I’m usually tired in the evenings and I try to do something else, whether is just cooking, home stuff..I just need some time off from the screen. But it’s also necessary to try and so some personal work...when I’m on the job I gather information both from photos, so I make a research of references and also based on my personal life experience and what the storyboard for episode tells.

But most of the time I sketch ideas based on my imagination and photo references, we also do a research on existing toys since the shapes on cartoons are very often stylized and simple...so looking at pictures of toys can help simplifying complex objects like props or vehicles!
the best process is sketching out what Is on my mind,do different options and If I’m struggling I take a look at pictures
I would suggest to do one project at a time...when I was doing my picture book after work Iwas really motivated to complete it because I wanted to present it in LA
also because I disliked my job so I needed something personal that was fun for me to work on:)
it’s perfectly fine if you are not inspired or less productive as long as you keep that under control and you force yourself as well to work more and more

Sometimes at work is not busy but generally my Supervisor always tries to give me some feedback or retakes to improve old concepts that are not yet into production for the episodes. But usually if the production is smooth there is always something new to design for the episodes. I would say overall my last experience was pretty chilled with few  busy moments.
If it’s very busy you could end up doing some overtime to meet the deadlines.
